Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master, A (1988)

simulated_ratings.title: Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child, A (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Overcooked slasher antics through a baby’s dreams felt gimmicky and low-stakes to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Scream (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever meta-mystery and tight suspense kept me engaged even if slashers aren’t my usual go-to.

simulated_ratings.title: Gremlins 2: The New Batch (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Chaotic satire with creature gags was fun if slight—more zany than thrilling.

simulated_ratings.title: Scream 2 (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Solid tension and whodunit beats but less fresh and impactful than the first.

simulated_ratings.title: Idle Hands (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stoner-horror silliness didn’t land for me, with laughs too lazy and stakes too soft.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Chewed Up (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Blunt, incisive bits and fearless honesty got good laughs despite the crudeness.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Shameless (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relatable riffs on family and marriage balanced the raunch and hit the mark.

simulated_ratings.title: 8 Heads in a Duffel Bag (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dark farce premise wears thin fast, with cartoonish chaos over character.

simulated_ratings.title: Stigmata (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Religious mystery angle intrigued me more than the jump scares, which felt routine.

simulated_ratings.title: Gremlins (1984)

simulated_ratings.title: 17 Again (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest second-chance charm and family heart worked well for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fault in Our Stars (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, sincere, and life-affirming in its love and loss themes.

simulated_ratings.title: Scarlet Letter, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Period romance and moral conflict interested me, even if the execution feels uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: Superstar (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy SNL sketch energy wore out its welcome despite a few sweet beats.

simulated_ratings.title: Hairspray (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Upbeat, inclusive spirit and big-hearted message won me over more than the musical style.

simulated_ratings.title: Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master, A (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive dream visuals aside, it’s repetitive slasher business that left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Pride (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Uplifting solidarity, humor, and courage across divides really resonated with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Dune (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand sci‑fi worldbuilding and mythic stakes scratch my epic itch despite rough edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Kick-Ass (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fierce, stylish action and offbeat heroism hit my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Live at The Comedy Store (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Loose, clubby set has sharp observations with a fair share of crude hits and misses.

simulated_ratings.title: Program, The (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gridiron pressures and moral choices engaged me, though it’s a bit melodramatic.

simulated_ratings.title: April Fool's Day (1986)

simulated_ratings.title: Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors, A (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Team-up dream battles add spice, but it’s still not my kind of horror.

simulated_ratings.title: Cinderella Story, A (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: Eddie Izzard: Circle (2002)

simulated_ratings.title: A Cinderella Story: Once Upon a Song (2011)

simulated_ratings.title: Citizen X (1995)

simulated_ratings.title: Comedy Central Roast of Bruce Willis (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Some sharp barbs and nostalgia, but the mean-spirited roast format is hit‑or‑miss for me.
